720061f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park West - Gramercy Park (North)
720061f-a.text:
4 to 1 (left to right) Gramercy Park West, south of, adjoining and at
the S.W. corner of Gramercy Park North. No. 4 (extreme left) is the
former residence of William F. Harper, one time Mayor of New York; No.
3, the home of the Netherland Club, and No. 1, the house once occupied
by Dr. Valentine Mott, distinguished physician, who was connected with
Bellevue Hospital.
About 1923.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
The New York Sun of June 2, 1939 reports the sale of No. 3, the
hone of the Netherland Club to Eugene Schoen, architect. The new
owier Nill convert this 75 year old structure into small apartments.
TPe Lee family were the owners from 1866 to 1912, when the estate
of Benjammin Franklin Lee sold same to the seller in the current sale.
Additional data regarding No. 1 Gramercy Park West, the former
residence of Dr. Valentine Mott,appeared in the New York Times
of September 24, 1941, Real Estate section.
720061f-a.folder: Gramercy Park West & Gramercy Park (North), Manhattan, NY

720058f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park West - Gramercy Park (North)
720058f-a.text:
1 to 7 dramercy Park West, west side, south from Gramercy Park
North, to and including Gramercy Park South. No. 1 (3orner house)
is the house once occupied by Dr. Valentine Mott, distinguished
pgysician who was connected with Bellvue Hospital. No. 3 (third
house) is the home of the Netherland Club. No. 4 is the former
residence of William F. Harper, one time Mayor of New York. No. 7
(7-story building) is the Christian Workers Home. This building is
now known (1937) as the Kennedy House.
April 1925.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
Additional data regarding No. 1 Gramercy Park West, the former
home of Dr. Valentine Mott, appeared in the real estate section
of The New York Times, September 24, 1941.
i1A ~9W

720059f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park West - Gramercy Park (North)
720059f-a.text:
1 to 7 Gramercy Jark West (center of view from right to left) west
from Gramercy Park North, to Gramercy Park South, as seen across the
south side of Gramercy Park horth and the Park, No. 7, the 7-story
building at the left, is the Christian Workers' Home. Also shown is
the 20-story Rex Cole (formerly Eagle) Building, at the S.E. corner of
East 21st Street and Fourth Ave.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
